reviewText: I remember seeing this movie on "The Wonderful World of Disney" when I was young. Then my daughter discovered it in a video rental store twenty-five years ago. It became her favorite and she named her own pony "Tonka." Now I'm surprising her with it as a gift for old times sake, and she'll share her memories with her children. Truly a Disney classic in every sense of the word. A family favorite for those who appreciate the times in which it was made.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Elise Triniol "A Great Old Movies Cine Buff"
reviewText: Based on actual events, this movie relates the story of a wild stallion, the only survivor of the 7th Cavalry from the bloody Battle of Little Big Horn. First; captured and tamed by a young indian White Bull (Sal Mineo), Tonka is claimed by the cruel cousin of the latter, White Bull decides to set him free. Later, he is captured and sold to the cavalry, he has a new master, Captain Keogh with whom he'll ride into Little Big Horn, when this one is killed, Tonka will avenge his death and become a hero in the 7th Cavalry.A real enjoyment for all horses'lovers !
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a true Disney classic & a real gem especially if you're old enough to remember seeing it as a kid. While I'd rank Tonka just behind Disney's: The Scarecrow of Romney Marsh, & The Prince & The Pauper w/ Guy Williams, & Davey Crockett, it is a great movie. I had been looking for this DVD for over 30 yrs, so I was delighted to find it again at Amazon. Sal Mineo does a great job of playing the young Indian that captures & tames the wild horse through gentle treatment & kindness. A very strong bond then develops between the two & their adventure continues. Tonka truly is "The Great One." Even if you're not a baby boomer & are considering getting this for your kids or grandkids, it's a great adventure, especially for animal lovers. *If you don't have the Disney Zorro series on DVD, you should definitely get that too.
summary: Tonka- for boomers & today's young kids as well

reviewText: I just recently decided to try and locate a copy of TONKA to see again. I remember what an exciting and moving film it was. I also remember reading the original novel (I think it was called COMMANCHE OF THE SEVENTH), which was told entirely from the point of view of the horse (Like today's Broadway hit - and future Spielberg film - THE WAR HORSE).  (It even included White Bull going through the gruesome "Sun Dance" that you can see in A MAN CALLED HORSE (I remember Tonka worrying that HE might be expected to do a Sun Dance).  Both book and film were excellent introductions to the U.S./Native American problems of the period (and as usual, Colonel Custer comes across as a handsome but pompous fool, which he probably was).  Vivid memory: Sal Mineo as White Bull, having captured Tonka, saying "You'd like to kill me, wouldn't you?" and the horse nodding vigorously.

reviewText: This is a fabulous story and well worth having... truly a Disney adventure classic in my personal opinion and if it were not for Amazon and other sites many of us would not even get to see these releases - Movie Club Exclusives.Most of us can only remember bits and pieces from those days when we would first see Tonka broken up for TV episodes but to see it in its wonderful entirety and wonderful remastered color, what a treat.For the memories alone you must get this release before it vanishes again and what a great Sunday evening treat when you settle down after dinner.There might be many who have become too politically correct to appreciate the characters and story and how they were represented and acted in those days but I might say take a look at the trash on our screens today. There will never again be tales of adventure like this, having that 'real' Disney feel and magic that just never seems to diminish - from the characters, the settings to the background music. Forget the new and return to the Golden Age of TV - you will feel a lot happier and contented that you have been entertained.

reviewText: My review is of the VHS of this story from Walt Disney, as we are awaiting this DVD release. I will update it if there are any changes from the VHS.THE STORY: In the 1870's, an Indian brave named White Bull (played by Sal Mineo) catches a stallion and names him Tonka. White Bull's more powerful cousin Yellow Bull is jealous and takes his horse away, but then abuses the horse. White Bull frees the horse, who eventually is owned by a U.S. Calvary Captain. The captain rides him into the battle with General Custer, where he is killed by the cousin Yellow Bull of all people, but the horse gets finally gets his chance at revenge. Tonka is retired by the Calvary as the only survivor and hero of the battle of the Little Big Horn. White Bull joins the cavalry, and is the only person allowed to ride Tonka as his exercise groom. "Tonka Wakan" means the Great One.BEHIND THE SCENES: The movie has a running time of 97 minutes in its VHS release. Originally conceived as a 5 episode television series, Walt Disney decided to use the material for a theatrical release instead. The movie premiered on December 25, 1958. It was directed by one of the "Zorro" show directors, Lewis R. Foster. He also took on the job of writer (Along with Lillie Hayward). Disney was one of the few studios where writers were often allowed to direct or produce their work. The screenplay was based on the book "Comanche" by David Appel. On location filming took place at the "Warm Springs Indian Reservation" in Oregon, where local residents worked as extras and crew. The director utilized the talents of cinematographer Loyal Griggs, famous for his work in western films such as "Shane". The scenery in the movie is stunning, with wide vistas in Technicolor.Long time Disney studio composer George Bruns wrote the song "Tonka" with Gil George, and another studio veteran wrote the background score, Oliver Wallace. The film returned to its original conception in a way when it was re-edited into a two episode film for Disney's weekly television show, the first episode titled "The Captive Stallion", and second was titled "The Lone Survivor of Custer's Last Stand". It began airing on NBC's "The Wonderful World of Disney" television show on February 18, and 25, 1962, and as a repeat on April 17, 24, 1966, and again on August 29, September 5, 1971. In 1977, Disney decided to air the film as a TV special on January 29, 1977, under the new name "A Horse Called Comanche". It was also edited under that title for serialization for "The New Mickey Mouse Club". The original film is what finally appeared on VHS in 1986. Looking forward to DVD release, and glad they are taking it off the shelf.
summary: Tonka Wakan means the Great One

reviewText: I remember seeing this one on the big screen when it first came out and I was a child in the middle of the Reservation. It was one of the few movies that had something to do with Native Americans and portrayed them as human beings. As such, I loved it. I rented an old VHS a few years ago and the color was terrible. Old magnetic tape tends to lose its sharpness almost immediately. Hey, Disney! Who were the original inhabitants of this land? Don't you owe them anything?

reviewText: . . . . but not holding my breath. Perhaps an old man is sittiing, fully clothed(!) reading this who was with Cousin Scottie and I at the 1959 Missouri Athletic Club Boys' Awards Banquet. You remember the 16mm 'scope' eidetic imagery , with crystal clarity you stir the old confused the emotions as well as we? "Tonka" stirred that young crowd that day, after the meal; after the nice embroidered patches; after the Little Big Horn..... Never had a performance moved me like Sal Mineo's until that day. It is a memory I will always cherish: when the young White Bull 'died', so did my childhood. Only the purely cinematic efforts of Ray Harryhausen over the next few years ("The 7th Voyage of Sinbad" comes to mind) could save it. I have come of course to love all of Sal Mineo's performances over the ensuing years, and have a few more to see. But "Tonka" must be seen again - perhaps with my grandsons next time. But I pray that by then that there will still  be some childhoods left.... Please help me petition Disney at their video website to release on DVD this classic western! Thanks! Tonka WAKAN: "The Great One"!
